Prerequisites

The text on this page aims to reinforce knowledge of the numbers we use today. Before starting, we suggest studying the following previous pages:

• Our sides are equal: in this first text, we show for people their body symmetry.
  • Couting: we introduce the idea of counting using our body.
  • Beyond fingers: exploring the limitations and the necessity of new tools to count.
  • Overcoming limits: Presentation of the logic behind the sequence between 0 and 19.
  • Numerical families: We study the Tens, along with the Ajawob dynasty that ruled the city of Copán, Honduras.

Introduction

Since the names of Maya leaders are generally not known to most people, we will use the terms "king" and "kings" in this text. However, we will always append the Maya terms ajaw (singular) and ajawob (plural) alongside them (McKinney, K. J., , pp. 14).

Altar Q depicts 16 generations of kings, known as ajawob in the Mayan language. The 16th king, Yax Pasaj Chan Yopaat, is represented alongside his 15 predecessors, emphasizing the continuity of his royal lineage. While the royal family may include other members, Altar Q specifically honors the line of kings (ajawob).

Reflection 1: Rules for Growth
Just as our height increases due to factors like nutrition, numbers also follow specific rules to grow. Some of these rules have already been introduced, but before proceeding, can you define some rules for increasing numbers?

Expanding generations and numbers

Based on our previous discussion, we can conclude that numbers increase according to the following rules:

1. Each digit in a number can have a value ranging from the minimum (0) to the maximum (9).
  2. When a digit reaches its maximum value (9), it resets to the minimum value (0), and the digit to its immediate left increases by one. If no digit is visible in the next position, it is assumed to be a "hidden" zero (0), representing an empty place (Musa, Auwalu, , pp. 44, 46 - 48).
  3. To change the leftmost digit again, the preceding digit must count from zero (0) to nine (9).

Just as people have names, so do the generations and positions in numerical order. Conclusion

In this text, we have expanded our understanding of numerical systems, particularly emphasizing that when a digit reaches its maximum value, the digit to the left increases by one. In the decimal system, the maximum value for any digit is 9. When all digits in a number reach their limit, the leftmost digit increases by one, while the other digits reset to zero. This observation leads us to an important reflection:

?
Reflexión 2: Is there a limit to numbers?
Decimal numbers consist of ten digits, ranging from zero (0) to nine (9). These digits set the limit for each position in the system. As we've seen, when a position reaches its maximum value, we can always add another digit by following specific rules. But this raises a critical question: is there a final number?

We pose this question to our readers but will refrain from answering it immediately. Instead, we will explore these concepts further to reinforce your understanding. In a few pages, we will provide the answer and introduce an important concept that has implications not only in mathematics but also in life.
